image.altText: People cross a city street.

items.synopsis: Growing concerns about crime and anti-social behaviour — coupled with media headlines pronouncing a "crime wave" — prompted police to ask for wider powers last month. But are they accurate?

title.children: Is there a crime wave happening in Adelaide's CBD?

image.altText: Business people walk past a shiny black sign that reads "Reserve Bank of Australia".

items.synopsis: Outgoing RBA governor Philip Lowe says Australia's economy has entered the "third phase" in its fight against high inflation. Here's what it means for interest rates and mortgages, and whether more rate rises are likely.

title.children: The RBA says the fight against inflation has entered a new phase. Here's what it means for interest rates

image.altText: A soccer team wearing yellow and green hugs each other after scoring a goal

items.synopsis: Find out where you can watch the Matildas in the FIFA Women's World Cup semifinal.

title.children: What time do the Matildas play tonight? Everything you need to know about the semifinal against England

image.altText: A group pf athletes in yellow shirts celebrate wildly.

items.synopsis: This is so much bigger than one team, at one point in time, in one FIFA World Cup. This is the story of triumph against a backdrop of toxic rhetoric about women and their capacity for sporting greatness, writes Patricia Karvelas.

title.children: The Matildas have risen against a toxic backdrop of rhetoric that sneered — women can't play soccer

image.altText: Pauline Hanson cocks her head to the side while looking down her nose between the shoulders of two men

image.altText: The Matildas hug, cheer and fist pump the air as they celebrate on the field.

title.children: As Mary Fowler and Caitlin Foord become household names, here's your pocket guide to the Matildas

image.altText: A group of women wearing yellow and green uniforms standing in a line jump in the air celebrating

items.synopsis: Australia and England have long-standing rivalries in men's sport, but for tonight's semifinal, how relevant are these old myths to these bright young teams?

title.children: Matildas' World Cup semifinal is not about old rivalries, but new mythmakers

image.altText: Matildas celebrate on field wave to crowd

items.synopsis: It is unconscionable to talk about the cost of a public holiday without also talking about the benefit. But there's something else that needs discussing too: declaring a public holiday is a job for states and territories. The PM doesn't get a look in, writes Peter Martin.

title.children: Why a public holiday for a Matildas World Cup win could cost far less than you think

image.altText: The captain of the missing boat, Yunardi Ardi, reunites with his family

items.synopsis: Search and rescue crews are continuing to scour the waters off Aceh for the final crew member of the wooden boat that went missing on Sunday night.

title.children: Indonesian boat captain details the last moment he saw missing crew member, as search goes on

image.altText: Jo O'Halloran wearing a blue top in a portrait.

items.synopsis: Medical scans cost some patients thousands in out-of-pocket expenses, and they are increasingly not covered by bulk-billing. But it's possible to save money by shopping around.

title.children: After Jo was diagnosed with cancer, medical bills started rolling in – and she has to pay thousands a year

image.altText: Oyster mushrooms

items.synopsis: Australia's mushroom industry says there's no chance poisonous mushrooms could enter commercial products, as the big supermarkets say fungi sales are still going strong.

title.children: 'Absolutely impossible' for toxic mushrooms to enter Australian supply chain, growers say

image.altText: A man on his phone in a yard.

items.synopsis: The financial complaints authority appears to have made inconsistent rulings on whether to give customers refunds after phishing scams, based on whether customers admit to clicking dodgy links.

title.children: In the space of two hours, scammers stole $16,000 from Roger's account. None of the transactions were caught by his bank

image.altText: Matildas fans show support during a 'Send Off Match' between Australia and France

items.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happened.

title.children: PM backs away from Matildas public holiday push. Catch up with The Loop

image.altText: Close up shot of Anthony Albanese.

items.synopsis: Boosting housing supply and reforming planning and zoning laws will be high on the agenda when national cabinet meets in Brisbane today, but the Greens are underwhelmed with renting measures that are already in place across most of the country.

title.children: National cabinet meets to discuss housing problems, with government's key policy stuck in the Senate

image.altText: A doordash bag hangs from the handlebars of an electric scooter

items.synopsis: An investigation by the communications watchdog finds DoorDash sent more than 1 million texts and emails that breached spam regulations.

title.children: DoorDash fined $2m for delivering too many spam messages

image.altText: A lady walking outside court with cameras in her face

items.synopsis: Alison Mibus, 43, has pleaded guilty to several charges, including holding herself out as a registered nurse, despite never being qualified in the profession.

title.children: Woman who posed as nurse doesn't remember administering vaccines on multiple occasions

image.altText: A generic photo of ASX board.

items.synopsis: Global markets fall sharply and Australian stocks lose more than 1 per cent at the open, while expectations remain that the US Federal Reserve may not be finished hiking interest rates. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Falls across ASX as China woes hit Wall St, European stocks

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Not a good start for the Australian stock market, with the ASX 200 down more than 1 per cent just a quarter of an hour into the session. And with 175 of the top 200 stocks in the red, it's fair to say the losses are broad-based. Here's how the sectors are faring so far: Looking at other markets around the region, South Korea's Kospi has lost 0.9 per cent since its session began a short time ago, while Tokyo's Nikkei 225 dropped by the same amount on the open. The NZ 50 is 0.7 per cent weaker.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX sheds more than 1 per cent in early trade

children.content: Not a good start for the Australian stock market, with
the ASX 200 down more than 1 per cent
just a quarter of an hour into the session.
And with
175 of the top 200 stocks in the red
, it's fair to say the losses are broad-based.
Here's how the sectors are faring so far:
ASX 200 sectors on Weds morning
(Refinitiv)
Looking at other markets around the region, South Korea's
Kospi
has lost 0.9 per cent since its session began a short time ago, while Tokyo's
Nikkei 225
dropped by the same amount on the open.
The
NZ 50
is 0.7 per cent weaker.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: While residential real estate may have been on the bounce over the past five or six months, rising interest rates have made property a bad sector to be in over the past year. Developer and landlord Mirvac has swung to a $165 million loss in financial year 2023, down from a $906 million profit the year before. The loss has been driven by write-downs in the value of its office (-5.6 per cent ) and retail (-5.3 per cent ) property portfolios, partly offset by a +6.2 per cent revaluation of its industrial properties. The company also sold off about $500 million of "non-core" assets at a 2 per cent discount to their book values, excluding the cost of the sales. Mirvac said it would continue to increase its exposure to residential and industrial real estate, while reducing the share of office space on its books, as the persistence of working from home dents demand in that sector. Excluding one-off costs, the company's "operating profit" dropped 3 per cent to $580 million. It will pay a 5.3 cent per share final dividend .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Mirvac highlights that property was not the place to be over the past year

in financial year 2023, down from a $906 million profit the year before.

per cent

"operating profit" dropped 3 per cent to $580 million
It will pay a
5.3 cent per share final dividend

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The corporate regulator has told insurers to lift their game when it comes to claims handling. A review by ASIC has found that general insurers can, and should, improve their claims handling processes and dedicate more resources, after identifying a number of weaknesses. "An insurance claim doesn’t have to be handled perfectly, but it must be handled well," ASIC deputy chair Karen Chester said. "Our claims handling review found good practices and poor practices across all six insurers. "We identified five areas where insurers can and should make immediate claims handling improvements — consumer communications, project management, identifying vulnerable consumers and complaints, resourcing of claims and complaints handling." The report was based on data from more than 200,000 claims lodged in the first three months of last year. Insurers included in the review included Suncorp, AAMI, Allianz, Budget Direct, QBE, IAG and Youi. Consumer advocates have welcomed the findings. "The insurance process can be stressful, especially in the wake of the extreme weather events that are happening more often, and I am delighted ASIC is telling insurers they must lift their game especially for people who are vulnerable," Consumer Action Law Centre managing lawyer Philippa Heir said. You can listen to a report from senior business correspondent Peter Ryan here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Do better, corporate regulator tells insurers

children.content: The corporate regulator has told insurers to lift their game when it comes to claims handling.
A review by ASIC has found that general insurers can, and should, improve their claims handling processes
and dedicate more resources, after identifying a number of weaknesses.
"An insurance claim doesn’t have to be handled perfectly, but it must be handled well,"
ASIC deputy chair Karen Chester
said.
"Our claims handling review found good practices and poor practices across all six insurers.

"We identified five areas where insurers can and should make immediate claims handling improvements — consumer communications, project management, identifying vulnerable consumers and complaints, resourcing of claims and complaints handling."
The report was
based on data from more than 200,000 claims lodged in the first three months of last year
Insurers included in the review included Suncorp, AAMI, Allianz, Budget Direct, QBE, IAG and Youi.
Consumer advocates have welcomed the findings.

"The insurance process can be stressful, especially in the wake of the extreme weather events that are happening more often, and I am delighted ASIC is telling insurers they must lift their game especially for people who are vulnerable,"
Consumer Action Law Centre
managing lawyer
Philippa Heir
said.
You can listen to a report from senior business correspondent
Peter Ryan
here:
